awd_titl_txt: Applications of Scalable Bases in Kernel Approximation
awd_abstract_narration:
1716927
Hangelbroek

     This project concerns research in the area of kernel-based meshless approximation methods, and applications to some large-scale scientific computing problems: numerical solution of partial differential equations (e.g., equations governing fluid flow), tomography (e.g., medical and seismic imaging), and scattered data approximation (modeling of irregularly sampled scientific data).  The main focus is on generation and use of scalable bases for kernel spaces; this is a new mathematical tool meant to stabilize and accelerate kernel-based algorithms.  Graduate students participate in the work of the project.

     The classical kernel approach is prized for its ability to provide accurate solutions to computational problems with complicated geometry; in this sense, it is a meshless method, which does not require sampling at uniformly placed sites or the careful construction of triangulations, meshes, or other apparatus.  However, it can suffer from instability and heavy computational costs when the underlying problems grow in size.  It has been shown that in some cases these drawbacks can be mitigated by construction of scalable bases (as developed by the investigator and collaborators), which can be efficiently generated and lead to stabilization of the underlying calculations.  The primary applications considered are threefold.  First is the development of an adaptive, meshless method for treating elliptic PDEs.  The notion of adaptive refinement of meshes is well understood for classical finite elements; this aspect of the project seeks to use the scalable bases local construction (where basis functions decay at a rate determined by the local density of the scattered centers) to develop an adaptive algorithm where the centers are refined, but no remeshing is needed.  Second, the investigator employs kernel-based quadrature, accelerated by using the scalable basis as a preconditioner, to treat tomographic problems.  The aim here is to develop parameter selection and error analysis for approximate filtered backprojection of tomographic data acquired from a certain class of phantom images.  Third, the investigator develops algorithms for scattered data-fitting that reflect local sampling density of the data.  Graduate students participate in the work of the project.

por.por_cntn:
Kernel methods are prized for their ability to provide accurate solutions to computational problems with complicated geometry. Such problems arise in diverse scientific fields, for instance as differential equations on exotic structures, or as data-fitting problems treating irregularly sampled data.

In a sense, kernels work independent of geometry. They do not require sampling at uniformly placed sites or the careful construction of regular triangulations, meshes, or other apparatus. However, they suffer from instability and heavy computational costs when the underlying problems grow in size. These drawbacks may be influenced and exacerbated when, additionally, the problem involves complicated geometry, either from irregular meshes employed by the kernel or because the underlying problem is situated on a region with a boundary.

In recent years, it has been shown that in some (geometrically simple)  cases these drawbacks can be mitigated by construction of scalable bases, which can be efficiently generated and lead to stabilization of the underlying calculations. During the funding period, the principal investigator conducted research in kernel-based approximation methods, focusing on using scalable bases to treat the above mentioned challenges. Outcomes are in three main directions: new applications for scalable bases, devising methods for scalable bases to treat irregular meshes, and devising methods for treating boundaries.

Applying the scalable basis technology to other settings:

  • developing scalable bases for divergence free, vector-valued kernel spaces.
  • using the basis "footprint" to serve as a stencil for kernel based finite difference schemes (called RBF-FD), a popular meshless method for solving time-dependent PDEs. As with standard FD, convergence of this method relies on two features: stability and consistency. Generally, consistency is automatic for RBF-FD, but stability has been a challenge to demonstrate. With collaborators we have shown that scalable bases can help to yield provably stable RBF-FD methods
  • developing an algorithm for anisotropic approximation with Gaussian mixtures. With collaborators, we show that performance of this algorithm in 2-d matches curvelet approximation (and is therefore optimal).

To treat irregular (i.e., non-quasi-uniform) meshes, we obtain results showing rapid decay and stability of local Lagrange bases under conditions of local quasi-uniformity, where there is a bounded local mesh ratio. This method has been implemented and tested on a number of irregular, 2-d meshes. To treat the large size of some of these examples, we have created a pre-conditioner which allows for rapid solution of interpolation problems.

For problems with boundaries, we have demonstrated the rapid, stationary decay of Lagrange functions in directions orthogonal to the boundary (decay parallel to the boundary is still an open question). This is a key step towards showing the existence of scalable bases in this setting.
